content:
• Wednesday, April 8, 2015
  • LGF.A

    Analysts weigh in on new guidance from Lions Gate

    • Analysts are coming in with new opinions as Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF -6.6%) revised previous guidance suggesting that it's tracking toward the lower end of EBITDA guidance (between $1.2B and $1.3B) in the three fiscal years ended March 31, 2017.
    • Shares declined today on the company's new commentary as well as the pricing of a 10M-share secondary that its biggest shareholder is exiting.
    • Attention focused on what may be underperformance at the studio's teen-focused tentpole adaptation franchises of The Hunger Games and Divergent; Piper Jaffray's James Marsh pointed to some light misses for the recent entries, The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1 and Insurgent (which has earned $106M domestically so far vs. $151M for the first film, Divergent).
    • Stifel's Ben Mogil also pointed to lower expectations for the profitability of the whole Divergent series as well as the upcoming Mockingjay Part 2 finale to the Hunger Games series.
    • FBR's Brian Neeley says MHR's outside sale doesn't mean LGF won't find a new strategic partner, notably including John Malone.
    • Previously: Maffei: More might come from Malone-Lions Gate relationship (Mar. 09 2015)
    • Previously: Starz, Lions Gate deal may presage closer relationship (Feb. 11 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:20 PM
  • MEMP

    Memorial Production Partners in 4.66M secondary offering

    • Memorial Production Partners (NASDAQ:MEMP) -2.6% AH after announcing a secondary public offering of ~4.66M common units owned by MRD Holdco, with an underwriters option to purchase nearly 700K additional units.
    • MRD Holdco will receive all net proceeds from the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:45 PM | 6 Comments
  • PIR

    Pier 1 Imports rallies following profit beat and strong guidance

    • Pier 1 Imports (NYSE:PIR) reports comparable sales rose 5.7% in FQ4.
    • E-commerce sales accounted for 11% of the company's total sales tally during the quarter.
    • Merchandise margin -100 bps to 55.6% as higher supply chains costs factored in.
    • SG&A expenses as a percentage of sales increased 140 bps to 27.4%.
    • Pier 1 says it plans to close 100 stores over the next three years as part of an optimization plan.
    • FY16 guidance: The company guides for a mid single-digit comp. EPS of $0.83-$0.87 vs $0.90 consensus estimate.
    • Previously: Pier 1 Imports beats by $0.03, misses on revenue
    • PIR +3.64% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 PM | 5 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

     
    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: SALT +8.4%. EPE +7.1%. RNDY +6.4%. APOG +5.6%. EGY +5.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: ZNGA -10.3%. NOAH -3.6%. BBBY -3.5%. AA -3.4%. GPT -3.0%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 2 Comments
  • XSPA

    Vringo posts 6.4% gain following ZTE breach of contract annnouncement

    • A Southern New York federal court has ruled ZTE breached an NDA with Vringo (VRNG) that formed the original basis of Vringo's U.S. claim against the Chinese IT/telecom equipment firm.
    • The court, which assumed control of Vringo's U.S. suit against ZTE in February, has also granted Vringo's requests to consolidate its NDA case and FRAND licensing case (previous) against ZTE for purposes of pretrial discovery, to extend the deadline for fact discovery, and to seal an unredacted version of Vringo's Motion to Compel.
    • Vringo also states a French infringement trial against ZTE will start on April 13, and that Brazilian "court-appointed experts" are finalizing reports Vringo believes will demonstrate ZTE's flouting of a local injunction that was upheld last month.
    • Shares rose to $0.745 in regular trading. They're up 35% YTD, but remain sharply below where they traded before last summer's adverse CAFC Google ruling.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:04 PM | 22 Comments
  • AA

    Alcoa slides after Q1 revenues miss expectations

    • Alcoa (NYSE:AA) -3.3% AH after Q1 earnings beat estimates but revenues fell short of expectations.
    • Alcoa upwardly revises its global aluminum demand growth expectations to 9%, totaling 54M metric tons, after predicting 7% demand growth earlier this year.
    • Also, AA continues to project ~3.5M metric tons of new demand growth in 2015, or 6.5%, for a record 57.5M metric tons of aluminum this year; it holds steady its 2015 growth projections for the aerospace, automotive, building and construction, industrial gas turbine and packaging end markets.
    • During Q1, Alcoa's primary metals business, which includes aluminum smelting operations, posted a Q1 operating profit of $187M vs. a year-earlier loss of $15M as average realized aluminum prices improved by ~10% from a year ago.
    • The engineered products division, which makes parts for airplanes, reported operating income rose 1% to $191M, but the rolled products division, which produces sheet aluminum for the auto industry, said its operating income fell 42% to $34M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:49 PM | 9 Comments
  • ZNGA

    Zynga -8.2% after resuming trading

    • The Street isn't pleased with news Don Mattrick is resigning as Zynga's (NASDAQ:ZNGA) CEO to pave the way for founder/chairman Mark Pincus' return.
    • After coming off a halt, shares have fallen to $2.66 AH. $1.2B in cash/investments ($1.31/share) were on the balance sheet at the end of 2014.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 16 Comments
  • SRC

    Spirit Realty files for 20M share secondary

    • The underwriter greenshoe is for another 3M shares. Money will be used to pay down the company credit line until needed for new acquisitions.
    • SRC -2.1% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • ZUMZ

    Double-digit sales growth for Zumiez in March

    • Zumiez (NASDAQ:ZUMZ) reports sales in March increased 11.1% to $70.7M.
    • Comparable-store sales were up 5.5% during the month.
    • ZUMZ +0.9% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM
  • MIND

    Mitcham Industries slips to six-year low on soft outlook

    • Mitcham Industries (MIND -3.8%) retreats to a six-year low after reporting last night that it swung to a Q4 net loss and revenue fell, even though the declines were smaller than analysts had expected.
    • Q4's unadjusted net loss was $9.2M ($0.76/share), reversing a $1.8M profit a year ago, while total revenues tumbled 37% to $15M; equipment leasing revenue, excluding equipment sales, fell nearly 22% from a year ago to $9.6M.
    • Looking to FY 2016, MIND sees demand for seismic services and equipment will remaining soft with limited visibility; it expects Q1 equipment leasing revenues to be somewhat improved from Q4 but says activity in Canada this winter was subdued and does not expect the region to contribute significantly to Q1 results.
    • Prior to today's session, MIND shares already had shed nearly two-thirds in value over the past 12 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • VIVHY

    Vivendi setting €6.75B in dividends to make peace with activists

    • Vivendi (OTCPK:VIVHY) and activist shareholder P. Schoenfeld Asset Management have reached a deal to end a tense fight, and the media conglomerate will propose a €2/share dividend that will push cash payouts to shareholders of €6.75B (about $7.3B).
    • Chairman Vincent Bolloré had been buying shares by the millions to increase his stake to 12% in a defensive maneuver as PSAM pressed the company to sell Universal Music Group and issue €9B in special dividends.
    • PSAM will withdraw two resolutions it planned to put before shareholders at the company's April 17 meeting: “Mr. Bolloré has demonstrated his sensitivity and willingness to respond to shareholder concerns."
    • If approved, the new dividend will be paid in two tranches, in Q4 of this year and Q1 of 2016.
    • Vivendi shares in the U.S. have climbed to +3.1%.
    • Previously: Vivendi fight: Bolloré raises stake again, to 12% (Apr. 02 2015)
    • Previously: Hedge fund accuses Vivendi chairman of loading up at low value (Mar. 30 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM
  • WBMD

    WebMD rebounds after Goldman does an about-face

    • Thinly-traded WebMD (WBMD +2.7%) moves up on a 3x surge volume after Goldman Sachs reverses its downgrade from Neutral to Sell back to Neutral. The firm says that it mistakenly included convertible notes when calculating diluted share count and net debt when it downgraded the company this morning.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 1 Comment

  • Israel ETF pops on Perrigo bid

    • What's the Market Vector Israel ETF (ISRA +2.9%) doing owning a 12% stake in Perrigo? It turns out Perrigo has a stock listing in Tel Aviv as well, thanks to its 2005 purchase of Agis Industries, then Israel's 2nd-largest drug maker.
    • In fact, Perrigo is the only non-Israeli company in the country's benchmark TA-25 Index.
    • The iShares U.S. Pharma ETF (IHE +2.4%) and the PowerShares Dynamic Pharma ETF (PJP +2.5%) are also on the move thanks to Perrigo.
    • Source: Barron's
    • Previously: Mylan makes $205/share bid for Perrigo; Generic firms rally (April 8)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM | 1 Comment

  • Notable tech gainers: ATHM, BITA, EBIX, QIWI, NEON, WYY, TUBE

    • With the Nasdaq up 0.7% and high-beta names performing especially well, only a handful of tech companies are posting outsized losses. A larger number are posting big gains.
    • Notable gainers include Chinese auto sites Autohome (ATHM +6.3%) and Bitauto (BITA +6.7%), insurance software firm Ebix (EBIX +4.8%), Russian online payments leader Qiwi (QIWI +5%), touchscreen tech developer Neonode (NEON +7.8%), IT services firm WidePoint (WYY +4.9%), and online video ad-buying platform TubeMogul (TUBE +4.4%).
    • Autohome and Bitauto have joined a long list of Chinese Internet stocks that have shot higher following an overnight rally in Hong Kong. Ebix is about $1.50 away from a 52-week high of $31.55. Qiwi is now up 9% on the week amid a broader rally in U.S.-traded Russian firms (aided by rising oil prices and a stronger ruble).
    • Previously covered: Yahoo, Rambus, Qualys, Digital Ally, Silicon Motion, Energous
     
     
     
     
    | 3:12 PM
  • BKD

    Brookdale Senior +3% on potential real estate sale

    • Brookdale Senior Living (BKD +3%) is considering selling its real estate unit to HCP (HCP -0.5%), according to dealReporter.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM | 3 Comments
  • EC

    Ecopetrol to tighten focus on offshore exploration, key fields

    • Ecopetrol (EC -2.1%) plans to cope with falling oil prices by bolstering exploration offshore, as well as focusing on production of high-yield wells, new President Juan Carlos Echeverry says.
    • EC will focus on ~20 oilfields that produce 80% of its onshore crude and have output costs of $7-$17/bbl, leaving wells with higher extraction expenses to other companies, Echeverry says one day after taking the helm at the company owned 88% by Colombia's government.
    • The new boss also says EC is prepared to take over operating duties at Colombia's largest oilfield, Campo Rubiales, after deciding not to renew the contract Pacific Rubiales had to run it.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:49 PM
  • WTM

    Bloomberg: White Mountains shopping OneBeacon

    • White Mountains Insurance Group (WTM +2.2%) owned 75.3% of OneBeacon Insurance Group (OB +6.7%) as of Dec. 31. According to the report, White Mountains has informally contacted bidders, but has no intention of being low-balled (who does).
    • Fosun International has expressed interest after losing out on the chance to buy Montpelier Re.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:34 PM
  • AABA

    Yahoo +3.3% thanks to Alibaba; big reorg reportedly planned

    • Alibaba is up 3.7% thanks to a big Chinese Internet stock rally, and Yahoo (YHOO) isn't getting left out of the fun. The company's 384M-share Alibaba stake is currently worth $32.7B.
    • Meanwhile, The Information reports Marissa Mayer is planning a big reorg that could reduce Tumblr's independence. Mayer has reportedly asked Tumblr founder/CEO David Karp which Yahoo SVP he'd like to report to.
    • A likely reason for the shakeup: The Information states Tumblr, which has continued seeing strong traffic growth since Yahoo's 2013 acquisition of the blogging platform, is unlikely to hit a $100M 2015 revenue target. Tumblr has been busy launching new ad formats, but some brands have been nervous about running ads against its content.
    • Also: Mobile product chief Adam Cahan might assume control of video products, and Simon Khalaf, CEO of leading mobile analytics platform Flurry (acquired last year) is reportedly being promoted to SVP, and could assume responsibility for Tumblr.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM | 7 Comments
  • RMBS

    Rambus up strongly amid heavy options buying

    • Rambus (RMBS +5.5%) is up 8.1% over the last two days. optionMONSTER observes nearly 6K August calls with a $15 strike price were purchased for $0.34-$0.50 yesterday. Those calls currently have a bid-ask of $0.60-$0.62.
    • On Monday, Rambus announced a partnership with engineering services firm Barco Silex to create hacking-resistant point-of-sale hardware. Target industries include banking, retail, transportation, and mobile. The alliance follows a slow of high-profile data breaches involving point-of-sale systems.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM
  • MRD

    Memorial Resource started with Buy rating at Global Hunter

    • Memorial Resource Development (MRD -3.6%) is initiated with a Buy rating and $25 price target at Global Hunter, which believes MRD has an asset base capable of generating impressive initial production rates and returns.
    • The firm says MRD is increasing activity and continuing to grow at an impressive pace where other E&P companies are slowing.
    • Global Hunter also likes MRD's veteran management team, clean balance sheet, ample midstream capacity and strong hedges, which gives investors a visible outlook on steady growth.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:09 PM
  • JBL

    Jabil makes fresh 52-week highs on Raymond James upgrade

    • Raymond James' Brian G. Alexander has upgraded Jabil (JBL +2.1%) to Outperform, and set a $27 target.
    • Alexander: "Reasons for our more constructive view: 1) less concern about near-term trends at Apple, 2) a recovery in [diversified manufacturing services] margins to +6%, 3) several new growth opportunities that could drive continued positive estimate revisions and 4) more clarity about capex and capital allocation priorities."
    • He isn't changing his estimates, but has "an upward bias" for them. "[W]e suspect that recent capex investments alone could drive over $0.50 of incremental EPS in FY17 vs. FY15, resulting in core EPS power above $2.75..."
    • Shares have made new 52-week highs. They rallied last month after Jabil beat FQ2 estimates and provided strong FQ3 guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:55 PM | 1 Comment

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: KONE +88%. AMCN +53%. OTC:QKLS +39%. CNYD +31%. SBSA +25%. CHNR +24%. PRGO +23%. YZC +23%. TEDU +21%. DSKY +19%.
    • Losers: FLML -12%. SYRX -11%. OTC:PSTR -10%. NADL -10%. BALT -9%. PQ -9%. NURO -9%. CEQP -8%. CAPN -8%. YUMA -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM
  • VECO

    Aixtron drops on Berenberg downgrade; Veeco also off

    • Believing LED equipment rival Veeco (VECO -2.3%) is better-positioned in China, Berenberg's Tammy Qiu has downgraded Aixtron (AIXG -2.5%) to Hold, and cut her target by €5 to €8 ($8.64).
    • Qiu thinks Veeco's solutions are more efficient and deliver greater automation, and that Aixtron provided leading LED manufacturer San'an favorable pricing to score a big order last year.
    • The downgrade comes as Aixtron announces the acquisition of PlasmaSi, a maker of thin-film encapsulation equipment for OLED production, for up to $16M in cash. OLED investments have been growing rapidly, thanks to both mobile demand and the nascent OLED TV and lighting markets.
    • In spite of Qiu's positive remarks, Veeco has followed Aixtron lower on an up day for tech. Shares are about $3 above a 52-week low of $27.80.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:43 PM
  • FENG

    Phoenix New Media CMO resigns

    • China's Phoenix New Media (FENG +10.2%) says its CMO, Ling Jin, has resigned effective immediately.
    • She'll work with the company until June 30 to enable a transtiion to a new chief marketing officer. She has agreed to remain beyond that, as a senior strategic adviser to the firm for another year, until June 30, 2016.
    • The company also promoted Andy Jin Xu to senior VP in charge of ad sales, marketing and branding activities.
    • Previously, Xu was managing director at J. Walter Thompson and CEO of LINTAS China.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:18 PM
  • ANGI

    Angie's List slips 5.8% on downgrade; Google getting into market?

    • Angie's List (NASDAQ:ANGI) has tumbled 5.8% as B. Riley goes Neutral on the stock, a downgrade from Buy.
    • The firm lowered its price target to $6.75, from $12.50. The stock closed at $6.07 yesterday and are now trading at $5.72. Analysts for the most part have Hold ratings on the stock.
    • Shares have now fallen 8.5% in the week and a half since Amazon.com announced its Home Services site to connect customers with local service professionals. BuzzFeed reports that Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) is considering a jump into the market as well later this spring, with a plan to connect Web searchers directly to local providers.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:51 AM | 5 Comments
  • RDS.A

    Shell-BG: "Dream combination" or deal "out of necessity, not strength"?

    • Royal Dutch Shell's (RDS.A -4.7%) $69.6B deal to buy BG Group is not going over well with investors so far, and analysts - while mostly positive - are not unanimously in support.
    • Raymond James, for example, and writes that BG’s assets are arguably “a perfect strategic fit” for Shell; aside from consolidating assets in the liquefied natural gas market to create the world’s largest independent LNG producer, the firm likes BG’s complementary assets from South America to Australia and Africa.
    • UBS, however, isn't so sure, seeing the deal proposed by Shell is "out of necessity not strength... there is a risk that Shell's portfolio is being marginalized in the current environment."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:36 AM | 8 Comments
  • JBAXY

    Julius Baer hits all-time high on Credit Suisse buyout rumor

    • “It’s just a rumor that comes out every three months, and a part of the market believes it,” says a skeptical Swiss trader. While Swiss private banking is in a tough spot at the moment making consolidation an interesting premise, he says no one is going to touch Julius Baer (OTCPK:JBAXY +2.9%) while it still has outstanding tax issues with the U.S.
    • "A merger with Credit Suisse  (CS -0.5%) just doesn't add up," says one analyst.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM
  • SALE

    Wunderlich: RetailMeNot to benefit as mobile commerce takes off

    • Adoption of mobile commerce is set to be a boon for RetailMeNot (SALE -1.9%), according to a new report from Wunderlich's Blake Harper.
    • Acceleration of mobile buying should help improve the company's monetization rate, to 25%-30% this year vs. last year's 20% -- "the single most critical factor for the stock," Harper says.
    • Revenues should benefit as conversion levels increase and "cross-device transactions" (where a consumer browses on a phone but finishes a transaction on the desktop) decline, and as more retailers take up in-store mobile promotions.
    • Wunderlich maintains a Buy rating on RetailMeNot. It had lowered its price target on the stock in February, to $28 from a previous $32. Shares are trading at $17.46.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:20 AM
  • RGC

    Janney Montgomery Scott cools off on Regal Entertainment

    • Regal Entertainment Group (RGC -1.7%) trades lower after Janney Montgomery Scott takes its rating down to Neutral from Buy.
    • Shares of Regal have held up decently since the company called off a plan to sell itself in January.
    • The company is considered a potential target due to its broad reach (42 states) and attractive properties (12.8 screens per location).
     
     
     
     
    | 11:08 AM
  • WHR

    Whirlpool and Electrolux lower after profit warning

    • Shares of Whirlpool (NYSE:WHR) are down 1.8% after rival Electrolux (OTCPK:ELUXF, OTCPK:ELUXY) warns on results in North America.
    • The Swedish appliance seller expects to post a loss in Q1 due in part to costs tied to energy regulations.
    • "Electrolux operations continue to be negatively impacted by the transition of the product ranges within refrigeration and freezers," reads the company's statement.
    • Electrolux will release full Q1 results on April 24.
    • Shares of Electrolux ADRs have fallen 7.7%.
    • Electrolux update on North American operations
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • QIHU

    Chinese Web/mobile stocks surge

    • Following a big overnight rally in Hong Kong (followed a 3-day holiday during which Shanghai rallied), beaten-down Chinese Internet and mobile stocks have soared in U.S. trading.
    • The biggest gainers include many names that are far below their 2014 highs: The group includes Qihoo (QIHU +10.5%), YY (YY +14.9%), Taomee (TAOM +14.3%), Sina (SINA +8.7%), and Weibo (WB +12.1%). Mobile game publishers Sky-mobi (MOBI +12.6%), China Mobile Games (CMGE +8%), and iDreamSky (DSKY +13.4%) are also sharply higher, as are online real estate plays SouFun (SFUN +13.1%), E-House (EJ +6.1%), and Leju (LEJU +9.8%).
    • Giants Alibaba (BABA +3.4%) and Baidu (BIDU +4.1%) aren't being left out. Neither are Youku (YOKU +7.5%), 21Vianet (VNET +7.4%), Momo (MOMO +6.8%), Sohu (SOHU +7.7%), Changyou (CYOU +4.5%), Dangdang (DANG +7.3%), Vipshop (VIPS +4.8%), JD.com (JD +3.9%), Jumei (JMEI +6.6%), Sungy Mobile (GOMO +5.8%), China Techfaith (CNTF +7.1%), and KongZhong (KZ +5.5%).
    • Alibaba has proposed an asset injection into its money-losing Alibaba Pictures (+36% in Hong Kong) film arm. Sky-mobi has seen Rosenblatt (Buy) hike its target to $11, while noting many Chinese mobile game developers have been bought out; it thinks Sky-mobi's investments in developers could be worth $140M. NetEase has been upgraded by CICC Research.
    • Over in Hong Kong, software/cloud services provider Kingsoft (OTCPK:KSFTF) rose 24.2% to HKD$29.50. Messaging/gaming giant Tencent (OTCPK:TCEHY) rose 3.3% to HKD$154.80.
    • ETFs: KWEB, CQQQ, QQQC-OLD
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM | 134 Comments
  • AMZG

    American Eagle Energy -15% following big Q4 loss, analyst Sell rating

    • American Eagle Energy (AMZG -14.9%) is sharply lower after reporting a larger than expected Q4 loss and announcing it entered into a forbearance agreement with four holders who collectively own or manage more than 50% face amount of its August notes.
    • AMZG shares are tagged with a Sell rating and $0.01 price target at Noble Financial, which estimates the fair value of company assets are below liabilities and believes the stock seems to be trading as an option value on oil prices rising, management renegotiating its debt, or a white knight buying the company.
    • Noble believes the likelihood of an outcome leaving equity investors with a positive value is rare and recommends investors avoid the stock at any price.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:49 AM | 1 Comment
  • VIV

    Vivo delays share offering by two weeks

    • Following a review by Brazil's CVM Securities Commission, Telefonica Brasil (VIV +1.5%) will delay a planned share offering by about two weeks, to April 28.
    • The company and its banks will wrap a roadshow and price on April 27, and shares should start trading in Sao Paulo April 29.
    • Shares have been trading down 15% YTD.
    • Previously: Telefonica Brasil to price share offering April 16 (Mar. 26 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:40 AM
  • SODA

    SodaStream bid higher with M&A still in the background

    • SodaStream (SODA +2.7%) is back over $20 on the back of a two-day rally.
    • The stock is getting pushed higher on M&A speculation, instead of financial performance, according to some traders.
    • Despite soft sales for SodaStream machines, some analysts have pointed out that the growth of the company's margins due to the shift in sales mix has been discounted.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:32 AM | 4 Comments
  • CHL

    China wireless firms spike on $24B asset injection

    • China's mobile firms have ramped up considerably today in U.S. trading as regulators work toward transferring 1M cell towers to a state-backed joint venture among the three.
    • The transfer to China Tower -- the joint venture between China Mobile (CHL +6.5%), China Telecom (CHA +9%) and China Unicom (CHU +4.2%) -- should allow the three to book a steroidal 148B yuan ($23.9B) in one-time gains.
    • Details of the transfer are sketchy, but China's government plans to wrap it by Aug. 15.
    • China Mobile holds a 40% stake in China Tower, and China Unicom and China Telecom split the remaning 60%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:30 AM
  • QLYS

    Qualys up 6.1% on Topeka upgrade

    • Believing new product launches will boost margins, Topeka Capital has upgraded Qualys (NASDAQ:QLYS) to Buy, and hiked its target by $15 to $61.
    • The cloud security/compliance software vendor has rallied to new highs. Shares soared in February thanks to a Q4 beat and strong guidance, and have benefited from investor enthusiasm towards cybersecurity plays in general.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:30 AM
  • NTES

    NetEase up 6% following CICC upgrade

    • Chinese sell-side firm CICC has upgraded NetEase (NASDAQ:NTES) to Buy, and hiked its target by $31 to $136.
    • The Chinese gaming giant has jumped to new highs. Shares are up 25% from a March 12 close of $94.83. A broader rally among Chinese tech firms is helping NetEase's cause today.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:15 AM

  • Hong Kong stocks hit seven-year high

    • Coming back from a three-day holiday in which Shanghai was consistently higher, the Hang Seng charged ahead by 3.8% overnight to its highest level since 2008.
    • Leading the gains were Hong Kong listings of Chinese companies which have severely lagged moves on the mainland over the past few months, leaving them at a 28% valuation discount. A gauge of such shares gained 5.8% last night, and inflows from China hit the ¥10.5B limit for the first time since the Hong Kong-Shanghai connect was opened in November.
    • EWH +3.7%
    • ETFs: EWH, EWHS, FCHI, FHK
     
     
     
     
    | 10:14 AM | 2 Comments
  • TSL

    Trina, Yingli drop on BofA/Merrill downgrades

    • BofA/Merrill has downgraded Trina (TSL -2.2%) to Neutral, and cut its target by $3 to $14. Yingli (YGE -1.6%) has been downgraded to Underperform, with its target cut by $2.20 to $1.60.
    • BofA says it's becoming more cautious on solar module makers, and sees ASPs declining thanks to a mix shift towards China relative to the U.S. and Japan. Margins are expected to be pressured by both pricing headwinds and trade disputes. The firm prefers upstream solar firms (e.g. polysilicon makers) and downstream firms (project developers) over companies with strong mid-stream (module) exposure.
    • Regarding Trina's downstream efforts, BofA argues most module makers have limited project experience. "Permitting, subsidy payments, and curtailment are the key challenges."
    • Trina rose last month after providing strong 2015 guidance to go with a Q4 revenue beat. Yingli tumbled after missing Q4 estimates thanks to declining ASPs and forex, and is now less than $0.15 above a 52-week low of $1.75.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:04 AM | 3 Comments
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate tumbles 7.2% after pricing 10M-share secondary

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) is trading down 7.2% after pricing an underwritten secondary offering of 10M shares at $32/share.
    • Mark Rachesky's MHR Fund Management -- Lions Gate's biggest shareholder -- will unload the shares, and Lions Gate won't receive any proceeds. He'll remain the largest holder after the deal, with about 29% of the company.
    • J.P. Morgan is sold underwriter for the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:02 AM
  • WATT

    Energous +3% on bullish Roth launch

  • EYES

    Second Sight implants next-gen device in preclinical study; shares jump 20% premarket

    • Recent IPO Second Sight Medical Products (NASDAQ:EYES) announces the first successful implantation of a mechanical model of its Orion I Visual Cortical Prosthesis in a preclinical animal study to evaluate the device's fit, form, stability and biocompatibility. The study will be completed later this year followed by active animal implants in Q1 2016. If all goes well, human trials will begin in Q1 2017.
    • The Orion I is based on the FDA-approved Argus II Retinal Prosthesis System, but with updates to the electrode neural interface, moving it from the retina to the surface of the visual cortex within the occipital lobe of the brain. This has the potential to help the 6M patients worldwide who have complete damage to their optic nerve or retina.
    • Shares are up 20% premarket on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM | 2 Comments

  • Nikkei hits 15-year high as BOJ keeps monetary taps on full blast

    • The Bank of Japan's board has voted 8-1 to keep its asset-purchase target at ¥80T a year, rejecting a call by stimulus critic Takahide Kiuchi to slash the goal to ¥45T. (PR)
    • As in the U.S., all that money printing has caused an inflation in assets, if not in consumer goods and services, and the Nikkei rose 0.8% to 19,789.81, the highest close since April 2000. The USD-JPY is -0.4% at ¥119.87.
    • Meanwhile, Japan's current-account surplus surged to ¥1.44T ($12B) in February from ¥61.4B in January and easily beat consensus of ¥1.15T.
    • The latest figure is the highest in almost 3 1/2 years and was boosted by increased income from overseas investments and the trade deficit narrowing to ¥143.1B from ¥864.2B.
    • A main reason for the trend is a drop in oil prices, which has made imports cheaper. The weaker yen is also helping.
    • The surplus, the eighth in a row, indicates that Japan has again become a large external creditor following a series of current-account deficits at the end of 2013. (PR)
    • ETFs: DXJ, EWJ, FXY, YCS, JGBS, DFJ, JGBD, JYN, NKY, DBJP, EZJ, EWV, JPNL, YCL, DXJS, SCJ, JSC, ITF, JGBL, JPP, JGBT, HEWJ, JGBB, FJP, QJPN, JPMV, DXJT, DXJH, DXJR, DXJF, DXJC

  • RDS.A

    More on Shell / BG Group: Shell offering a 52% premium

    • Based on a 90-day trading day average, Shell's (RDS.A, RDS.B) offer is worth 1,350 pence per BG (OTCQX:BRGXF) share, or a 52% premium to the latter's price of 890.4 pence.
    • The acquisition will add 25% to Shell's proven oil and gas reserves and 20% to production, and improve the company's prospects in new projects, particularly in Australia LNG and Brazil deep water.
    • Shell expects the transaction to generate pretax synergies of $2.5B a year.
    • In addition, Shell plans to increase asset sales to $30B from 2016-2018 - the company said in January that it would sell $5-6B worth of assets per year.
    • Shell intends to pay dividends of $1.88 per ordinary share in 2015 and "at least that amount in 2016." The company also expects to start a share buyback program of at least $25B from 2017 to 2020.
    • Shell -1.9% in London while BG Group is +39.2%. (PR)
